utterances: Women of every other culture wear weaves, and I think in our - actually, I know that Caucasian women, Spanish women, they have been wearing weaves before black women have been wearing weaves.
Well, let me ask you this.
Is the stigma still there though?
Because you know, there used to be such a stigma because the black people get into this good hair, bad hair thing and if you have a weave, you must have bad hair because, you know...
But the stigma is definitely still there.
I still get clients that come into the salon and they sit in my chair and you know, (laughing) they have this frown on their face and they wished they had good hair.
I just think, you know, we start with our kids now to break this horrible cycle.
We start with our kids and we let them know, there's no such thing as good and bad hair.
I think if you have hair on your head, and I think if it's healthy hair, it's good hair.
If your hair is unhealthy, it's bad hair.
My grandma, used it a long time, you know, oh, your hair is good, on your forehead, that's bad hair.
That's all it breaks down to.
I don't think the texture matters or if you are 10 percent, 50 percent Indian, two percent white, whatever it is...
OK, let me ask you this.
This has been going on, the good hair, bad hair, I mean...
It's passed down through generations and now, white girls that I see are (laughing) more than happy to sit back with black girls and compare weaves.
Pull or pull out their hair and say, OK, I got mine at this place.
What I don't understand about the stigma, particularly when, you know, African-American men complain about is like, now you have sisters and mothers, now you know exactly how this works.

I have a couple of those African-American male clients who sit up in my chair and they talk about the woman they would love to meet and love to date and love to marry, and they always say they want this woman without a weave.
It's 2009 and for all of you who are looking for a woman without a weave, good luck.
I suggest you just - I was going to say, go to Africa, but she's not even there anymore.
They wear weaves in Africa, too.
So yeah, they wear weaves in Africa.
But I always say Beyonce wears weaves.
So what are you going to do?
Does she - I have a special supplier where I go get my Indian hair.
And when I walk in there, about 50 percent of the women that are in there are non-African-American.
And there's not that stigma for whatever reason.
Well, I just want to say, I will wear one of them in a minute and I keep my hair in the car.
I keep my hair in the glove compartment in case I need to, you know...
